abstract.p: Sampling of winter gardening events in Westchester County, NY; drawings (Special Issue: Entertainment) (M)

AVID gardeners know that fall is a time to get back out into the beds and borders. The weeds grow, rain or shine, and all those garden center bargains have to be planted before the nights begin to get frosty.
There will come a time, though, when even the most fanatic gardener decides to hang up the tools and take a rest from hands-on activity.
October, November and December are good months to meet other gardeners and learning from them. Plant societies, botanical gardens and arboretums sponsor many events, lectures, classes and shows.
Here is a sampling of events:
African Violets

Many gardeners devote the winter to African violets and other members of the gesneriad family. The Long Island Chapter of the American Gloxinia and Gesneriad Society will present a session on creating floral designs with gesneriads at their free monthly meeting on Oct. 14.
The chapter's meetings take place the second Saturday of each month at Clark Botanic Gardens, 193 I. U. Willets Road in Albertson, N.Y., and start at noon with a plant sale.
Information: Paul Susi at starz @worldnet.att.net, Marcia Degner at bdegner@redconnect.net or the botanic gardens at (516) 484-2208.

Violets, gloxinias and other gesneriads will also be in the spotlight twice this fall at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum in Morristown, N.J. Today from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. the Frelinghuysen Arboretum Gesneriad Society will hold its annual show and plant sale, ''Gesneriads Get My Vote.'' Information: Jeanne Katzenstein, (973) 627-2755 or jkatzenste@aol.com.

The second gesneriad show is scheduled Nov. 4 from 1:30 to 5 p.m., and on Nov. 5 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., when the arboretum will be the host for the Tri-State African Violet Council Judges' Show. For information, call the arboretum at (973) 326-7600.
Bonsai
The Bergen Bonsai Society celebrates the ancient Japanese art of training and pruning trees with a busy calendar of shows and events.

The annual Bonsai Show and Critique will take place on Oct. 15, and on Oct. 29 the society will sponsor a collecting trip to the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye. On Nov. 12 Arthur Skolnic of Toronto will lecture and demonstrate how to create a bonsai using false cypress. Observers are welcome at an afternoon workshop the same day, when 10 society members work on 10- to 20-year-old cypress trees under Mr. Skolnic's direction. All meetings take place at the Closter Nature Center on Ruckman Road (between Hamans and Piermont) in Closter, N.J., beginning at 9:30 a.m. Information: Mitchell Becker at mitand@worldnet.att.net.
Chrysanthemums

Chrysanthemums are the longtime stars of the fall garden. They can be seen in their glory when the Planting Fields Arboretum plays host to a chrysanthemum show next Saturday and Sunday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (516) 922-9201.

The New Jersey State Chrysanthemum Show at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum in Morristown, N.J., will be held next Saturday and Sunday. Mums of all types and colors will be exhibited, judged, discussed and sold both days from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Information: (973) 326-7600.
Dahlias

On Long Island, the Mid Island Dahlia Society concludes its annual show today at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Dahlias will be on display in a special outdoor garden as well as in indoor exhibits. Information: (516) 922-9201.
Herbs

Anyone with a yen to learn more about herbs can attend the meetings of the Northern New Jersey Unit of the Herb Society of America on the second Thursday of the month from 10:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum in Morristown. On Oct. 12, the topic will be ''Making Dried Wreaths Extraordinaire'' and on Nov. 9, ''Herbal Lotions, Creams and Tinctures.'' Information: Betty Robrecht at (908) 769-5640.
Orchids

The American Orchid Society's Joint Presidents Council Orchid Speakers Day on Nov. 4 is an event for orchid fanciers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. At the conference, scheduled from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and presented by affiliated societies in the area, authorities will discuss various aspects of orchid culture and scholarship. Speakers and their topics will be Pedro J. Martinez (''Indigenous Orchids of Venezuela''), H. P. Norton (''Phaleonopsis Hybrids''), Karsten Woodrich (''Indigenous Orchids of South Africa'') and Dr. Kim Wing Yam (''Orchids of the Singapore Botanical Garden''). Advance registration is required: send $30 a person, plus name, address, telephone number and e-mail address (if applicable), to Joe Reider Jr., 94-62 217th Street, Queens Village, N.Y. 11428. Information: Mr. Reider at (718) 776-0929.
Rhododendrons
Rhododendron enthusiasts are almost as numerous as the plants that they admire, and so are rhododendron-related events this fall.

The New York chapter of the American Rhododendron Society meets on the third Thursday of each month at 8 p.m. at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Dr. Steve Krebs, an Ohio rhododendron expert, will speak Oct. 19 about ''Rhododendron Research at the Holden Arboretum.'' On Nov. 16 the speaker will beBud Gehnrich, whose topic will be ''Seeking Our Native American Azaleas.'' Information: Jim Fry, (631) 754-2412.

Dr. Krebs is also speaking in New Jersey on Oct. 18 at 8 p.m. in an appearance sponsored jointly by the Princeton and New York chapters of the rhododendron society. The place: the First Presbyterian Church of Hightstown, 320 North Main Street. Information: Henry Schannen, (732) 833-1439.

The Tappan Zee chapter of the rhododendron society generally meets at 8 p.m. once a month in Park Ridge, N.Y., at the United Methodist Church, 130 Verthould Street. The Oct. 25 meeting will include a discussion of ''Dexter Hybrid Rhododendrons'' by Jonathan Leonard. On Nov. 29, Mark Brand of the University of Connecticut will speak on rhododendron culture. Information, Alexander Fitzburgh at (973) 226-5796.
Horticultural Societies

The Long Island Horticultural Society meets at 2 p.m. on the third Sunday of each month at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Meetings are open to the public for a $5 fee. On Oct. 15, Stephanie Cohen, an author and designer, will talk about ''Native Plants for Herb Borders.'' Ed Morith will discuss fragrance in the garden on Nov. 19, and on Dec. 17, Ellen Talmadge, an author, will lecture on ''Gardening Fun With Kids.'' Information: (516) 922-9201.
Arboretums

Fall is Harvest Festival time at Reeves-Reed Arboretum in Summit, N.J. The family-oriented event will take place on Oct. 14 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Many of the activities will be geared to children: they can select their own pumpkins in a pumpkin patch and get lost (temporarily) in a hay maze. Pony rides, face painting and a petting zoo will also be featured. Admission: $5 a person; children under 5, free.

Like other local botanical gardens, the Mary Flagler Cary Arboretum Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y., has a full schedule of trips and horticultural and crafts classes. Information: (914) 677-9643.

In addition to its regular classes, the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay will have a symposium on new plants on Oct. 27 from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Registration required. Information: (516) 922-9201.
